questions.text: A previously healthy 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 35 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He was ambulatory at the accident scene, with stable vital signs and no major external injuries except abrasions to both upper extremities. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/74 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows ecchymosis over the upper abdomen, with tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. There is no guarding or rigidity. Rectal examination is unremarkable. A CT scan of the abdomen with intravenous contrast shows a subcapsular splenic hematoma, with no contrast extravasation and minimal blood in the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In patients with splenic injury who are hemodynamically stable, nonoperative management is warranted and consists of observation, pain management, and serial abdominal examination (including ultrasound) and hemoglobin and hematocrit measurement to monitor any further complications that may develop.

Surgical intervention is indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy and splenectomy are indicated for hemodynamically unstable patients with hilar rupture.

C) INCORRECT:

As this patient is hemodynamically stable, a nonoperative approach is suitable. Because there is a significant risk that the splenic injury may progress, leading to rupture and intraabdominal bleeding, another course of management is more appropriate than analgesia and discharge home.

D) INCORRECT:

Laparotomy and partial splenic resection are indicated in peripheral splenic rupture, which this patient could have, given the subcapsular hematoma. However, this procedure is most appropriate for hemodynamically unstable patients.
questions.hint: Tenderness of the left upper quadrant and a subcapsular splenic hematoma on CT scan following significant trauma indicate splenic injury. This patient's normal heart rate and blood pressure indicate that he is currently hemodynamically stable.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of left shoulder pain after falling from a height of approximately 10 feet while rock climbing 5 hours ago. He initially thought the pain would resolve with rest but it became more severe over the last 2 hours. Last year while rock climbing he fell onto his right shoulder and “needed a sling to fix it.” He has psoriasis. His only medication is topical clobetasol. His pulse is 95/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 114/70 mm Hg. Examination shows full passive and active range of motion of the left shoulder. There is no tenderness to palpation at the acromioclavicular joint. There are silvery plaques over both knees and elbows. Abdominal examination shows severe tenderness to palpation in the left upper quadrant with voluntary guarding. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes are within the reference range. Chest x-ray is normal. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows no evidence of free intraperitoneal fluid. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Serial vital signs for at least nine hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The severity of abdominal injury determines whether hemodynamically stable patients can be managed nonoperatively with serial monitoring of vital signs. Although unsupported by high-quality evidence, serial monitoring of vital signs for a period of 9 hours without imaging may be a reasonable approach following trauma for hemodynamically stable patients with a low risk of abdominal injury. This patient, however, has fallen from a height of 10 feet and has left upper quadrant pain and guarding, as well as a positive Kehr sign, all of which indicate a splenic injury that requires additional abdominal imaging.

B) CORRECT:

Abdominal CT with contrast is the most appropriate next step, following a negative FAST scan, in the management of a hemodynamically stable patient with a suspected splenic injury. CT scan has greater specificity than ultrasonography for diagnosing splenic lacerations because it can visualize the vasculature and parenchyma of the spleen in high resolution. Findings on the CT scan are used to grade splenic injury and guide further management. CT scan can also rule out other concomitant injuries in cases of abdominal trauma, especially injuries involving retroperitoneal structures.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane; portal venous phase) of a 24 year-old patient after a high-speed front-impact crash

The spleen has an irregular contour (dashed outline) and heterogeneous enhancement. Intrasplenic low-attenuation rounded and linear areas are sites of laceration and hematoma formation. Multiple small high-density foci along the inferior aspect of the spleen indicate contrast extravasation (arrows) from active bleeding.

Hemorrhage (green overlay) into the peritoneal space extends from the spleen inferiorly along the paracolic gutter. Hemorrhagic fluid is also seen along the liver (yellow overlay) and within the right paracolic gutter and pelvis (yellow overlay).

Multiple thoracic spine fractures (examples indicated by arrowheads) are accompanied by paravertebral hematoma (red overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) is a procedure that can be used in patients with blunt abdominal trauma to determine the presence of blood within the peritoneum. DPL should only be considered in hemodynamically unstable patients who have an inconclusive FAST scan. However, this patient is hemodynamically stable and a FAST scan was negative for free intraperitoneal fluid. In addition, although highly sensitive, DPL has largely fallen out of favor because it is an invasive procedure; it may, however, be necessary in some cases (e.g., in resource-poor settings).

D) INCORRECT:

Shoulder radiographs are the first-line imaging modality in the diagnostic workup of traumatic shoulder injury (i.e., clavicle, proximal humerus, or scapula fractures; acromioclavicular or glenohumeral dislocations). However, the combination of left upper quadrant tenderness and guarding, onset of left shoulder pain a few hours after the initial trauma, and a normal shoulder joint examination indicates that this patient's acute shoulder pain is most likely the result of referred pain due to diaphragmatic irritation (Kehr sign) rather than a traumatic shoulder injury.

E) INCORRECT:

An exploratory laparotomy is a surgical procedure that encompasses examination and treatment of the intraabdominal cavity for sources of bleeding in patients with blunt abdominal trauma. It is typically performed in hemodynamically unstable patients following the confirmation of free intraperitoneal fluid. This patient is hemodynamically stable and initial diagnostic imaging shows no evidence of intraabdominal bleeding. Therefore, an exploratory laparotomy is not appropriate at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

Left upper quadrant tenderness and guarding, the onset of left shoulder pain a few hours after the initial trauma, as well as a normal shoulder joint examination, indicate that the shoulder pain in this patient most likely results from referred pain due to diaphragmatic irritation (Kehr sign), and is not the result of a traumatic shoulder injury. If shoulder injury were suspected, a shoulder MRI could be useful to image soft tissue of the shoulder such as the rotator cuff and acromioclavicular ligaments. However, MRI is not the first-line of imaging in a patient with a suspected traumatic shoulder injury.
questions.hint: Left upper quadrant abdominal pain, voluntary guarding, and referred shoulder pain (Kehr sign) in a patient who has fallen from a significant height indicates splenic injury.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 35 minutes after falling off a horse. Her mother reports that she lost consciousness for fewer than 15 seconds. She reports pain in her left shoulder, left flank, and left hip. She has no history of serious illness but had a sore throat, fatigue, and fever for the past week. She does not take any medications. Her pulse is 105/min and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abrasions on the left upper arm, but no signs of fracture or dislocation. Passive and active range of motion of the shoulder, elbow, and wrist are intact. There is abdominal tenderness and guarding in the left upper quadrant. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 5600/mm3, and platelet count is 145,000/mm3. An abdominal ultrasound shows free intra-abdominal fluid in the Douglas pouch. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's sonographic findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal pain and guarding, shock, and free intra-abdominal fluid after abdominal trauma raise suspicion for small bowel perforation. However, while penetrating abdominal trauma (e.g., gunshot, knife wound) leads to immediate bowel injury and intestinal leakage, blunt abdominal trauma (e.g., this patient's fall) typically results in an intestinal contusion, which slowly develops into necrosis and intestinal rupture after several days. This patient's acute presentation after a fall makes another diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Abdominal pain radiating to the shoulder and abdominal guarding after a fall may raise suspicion for liver hematoma. However, liver hematoma is associated with right upper quadrant pain that radiates to the right shoulder, not left upper quadrant pain radiating to the left shoulder. Moreover, in the absence of liver parenchymal disruption, a liver hematoma is an encapsulated collection of blood and would not present with hemoperitoneum (i.e., blood in the rectovaginal pouch of Douglas).

C) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic laceration may occur in blunt abdominal trauma (e.g., this patient's fall), causing abdominal pain and guarding. However, pancreatic laceration is associated with right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, not left upper quadrant pain that radiates to the left shoulder. Moreover, because the majority of the pancreas is retroperitoneal (only the tail is intraperitoneal), pancreatic laceration is more likely to manifest with a retroperitoneal or peripancreatic hematoma than with blood in the pouch of Douglas.

D) CORRECT:

Left upper quadrant pain radiating to the left shoulder (Kehr sign), abdominal guarding, and hemorrhagic shock (tachycardia, decreased hemoglobin) after blunt abdominal trauma in a patient with a recent history of infectious mononucleosis (IM) is consistent with splenic rupture. IM is associated with splenomegaly, so affected individuals have an increased risk of splenic rupture and are therefore advised to avoid physical activity for at least 3 weeks after the onset of symptoms. This patient's fall from a horse likely caused splenic rupture, resulting in hemoperitoneum and blood collection in the pouch of Douglas, as seen on this patient's abdominal ultrasound.

E) INCORRECT:

The kidney may be damaged in blunt abdominal trauma (e.g., this patient's fall), which can manifest with abdominal pain. However, kidney injury is not typically associated with pain that radiates to the left shoulder. Moreover, because the kidney is a retroperitoneal organ, free-fluid collection in the rectovaginal pouch of Douglas would not be expected in the absence of penetrating trauma, because the posterior border of the pouch is the peritoneum. Furthermore, kidney injury is typically associated with hematuria, which is not seen here.
questions.hint: This patient most likely presents with a serious complication of infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 2, is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of acute abdominal and left shoulder pain, nausea, vomiting, and hiccups. She has no history of trauma to the region and has been well until the onset of the current episode. Her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. She has had two miscarriages but otherwise has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She appears to be in acute distress. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 65 kg (143 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. There is left upper quadrant tenderness with localized guarding. There is no rigidity or rebound tenderness. The spleen tip is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. The liver edge cannot be palpated. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
15 g/dL


Leukocyte count
14,000/mm3



Platelet count
270,000/mm3



Prothrombin time
12 seconds


Partial thromboplastin time
45 seconds


Serum



Urea nitrogen
16 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


Lactate dehydrogenase
250 U/L


A transverse section of a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen is shown. Treatment with intravenous fluids and analgesics is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Splenectomy is indicated in the treatment of splenic infarction if complications develop (e.g., hemorrhage, atraumatic rupture, aneurysm formation, pseudocysts) or if symptoms persist despite adequate treatment. While this patient's features (e.g., left upper quadrant pain, vomiting, splenomegaly) and CT findings are consistent with splenic infarction, there is no evidence of a complication.

B) INCORRECT:

CT-guided aspiration can be used in the treatment of unilocular splenic abscess and nonparasitic splenic cysts (e.g., epidermoid cyst, lymphangioma), both of which can manifest with left upper quadrant pain and splenomegaly. On a CT scan, splenic abscesses appear as round cavitary lesions with central hypodensity, sometimes with peripheral contrast enhancement, and nonparasitic splenic cysts typically appear as round hypodense lesions with thin, smooth, well-defined walls and no peripheral enhancement. This patient's CT findings indicate a different diagnosis, which requires another treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics are indicated in the management of splenic abscess, which typically results from septic embolization (e.g., due to infective endocarditis) or superinfection of a preexisting splenic infarction. While a splenic abscess can manifest with left upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, splenomegaly, and leukocytosis, a CT scan would show a round cavitary lesion that has a central hypodensity and, occasionally, peripheral contrast enhancement. This patient's CT findings indicate another diagnosis, for which antibiotic therapy is not indicated.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (with IV contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a splenic abscess

A solitary low attenuation lesion (green overlay) in the region of the spleen contains small collections of gas (arrowheads) and a gas-fluid level.

The presence of gas in a splenic lesion is an uncommon but characteristic finding of abscess.

A: aorta; Arrow: transverse diameter; G: gas; GB: gallbladder; IVC: inferior vena cava; K: kidney; L: liver; P: pancreas; S: spleen

D) CORRECT:

The CT scan findings in this patient are consistent with splenic infarction, which can manifest with left upper quadrant pain, features of ipsilateral diaphragmatic irritation (e.g., Kehr sign, hiccups), vomiting, splenomegaly, leukocytosis, and elevated LDH. In patients < 40 years of age, the underlying cause of the infarction is most commonly a hypercoagulable state, whereas the etiology in patients > 40 years of age is most often thromboembolic. Thrombophilia testing, including serology for antiphospholipid antibodies, should be performed to identify the underlying cause of nontraumatic splenic infarction. This woman's history of miscarriages and her prolonged partial thromboplastin time suggest antiphospholipid syndrome. The use of oral contraceptives further increases the risk of developing thrombi. If the patient has an underlying hypercoagulable state, anticoagulant therapy is required in addition to hydration, analgesics, and close monitoring. Symptoms typically resolve within 1–2 weeks in uncomplicated cases. Follow-up imaging is required to screen for complications (e.g., hemorrhage, pseudocyst, abscess). If complications develop or symptoms persist, splenectomy may be required.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (left upper quadrant; with IV contrast; axial plane) of patient with history of atrial fibrillation and acute left upper quadrant pain

A sharply demarcated hypodense area (green overlay) is seen in the medial spleen (S). Capsular enhancement is preserved.

The finding represents a splenic infarction. Infarctions may be single or multiple and typically appear as hypoenhancing or nonenhancing lesions, often wedge-shaped. Imaging features can vary with stage. Acute infarctions may appear heterogeneous and contain sites of hemorrhage. Chronic infarctions may disappear or liquify and become cystic. They may also result in parenchymal scarring, seen as splenic volume loss and distortion.

A: aorta; C: colon; L: liver; red overlay: splenic artery

E) INCORRECT:

Angiographic embolization of the splenic artery is used in the treatment of hypersplenism if severe symptoms (e.g., pancytopenia) are present. This patient has splenomegaly, but the acute onset of symptoms and the lack of cytopenia are not consistent with hypersplenism. Moreover, she has no medical history of conditions associated with increased splenic activity (e.g., liver disease, malaria, leukemia).
questions.hint: The CT scan shows a wedge-shaped noncontrast enhancing lesion in the spleen. This patient's condition also occurs repeatedly in children with sickle cell disease (SCD) before 4 years of age, albeit by a different mechanism (secondary to vasoocclusion from sickle cell buildup).

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after colliding with another player during a soccer game. Since the collision, she has developed abdominal pain that is steadily getting worse.
She had a sore throat 2 weeks ago, but her medical history is otherwise unremarkable. She has not yet started menstruating and is not sexually active.
Her abdomen is mildly distended and diffusely tender, with focal pain over the left lower rib cage. A bedside ultrasound demonstrates trace free fluid in the pelvis.
What is the most likely cause of this patient's abdominal pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian torsion occurs infrequently in premenarchal girls. Most cases occur in women of reproductive age and manifest with pelvic pain, nausea, vomiting, and an adnexal mass.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's history and presentation are concerning for splenic rupture, a rare but worrisome complication of infectious mononucleosis.

Splenomegaly occurs in 50% to 60% of cases of infectious mononucleosis, but splenic rupture occurs in only 0.1% to 0.2% of cases, usually within the first 3 weeks of symptom onset (headache, sore throat, and fever). During this time frame, the splenic architecture is thought to be distorted, leaving the spleen vulnerable to rupture.

Most splenic ruptures are spontaneous, but there is concern that some may be precipitated by trauma. Rupture is associated with abdominal pain, left shoulder pain (Kehr sign), or pericapsular pain. Although rarely fatal, indicators of hypovolemia (such as tachycardia and hypotension) are worrisome. Splenic rupture can typically be treated conservatively without surgical intervention.

Although the FAST (focused abdominal sonography for trauma) examination is frequently used in adult trauma centers to screen for intraperitoneal free fluid, it is less definitively useful in children, with sensitivity rates ranging from only 56% to 75%. Thus, the lack of large amounts of free fluid on ultrasound does not rule out splenic rupture in this child.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an adolescent who develops acute abdominal pain after a collision in a soccer game and who has a recent history of sore throat is splenic rupture.

C) INCORRECT:

Rupture of an ovarian cyst can occur as a result of trauma but is usually limited to postmenarchal females who are ovulating. Rupture of an ovarian cyst typically manifests with lower abdominal and pelvic pain.

D) INCORRECT:

In the case of a rib fracture, one would expect to find point tenderness over the affected ribs without abdominal findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Perforation of the descending colon does not typically manifest with acute findings but rather with later findings indicative of evolving peritonitis. Colonic perforation tends to occur only after major trauma, such as a motor vehicle crash.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy presents to the Emergency Department after a bicycle accident. He complains of mild left upper quadrant abdominal pain but has no difficulty breathing. He shows no signs of hemodynamic compromise. Laboratory results show hemoglobin 120 g/L (reference range: 115–155 g/L) and a normal coagulation profile. He remains comfortable with stable vital signs throughout a three-hour observation (see report).


Heart rate
98/min


Blood pressure
105/70 mm Hg


Abdominal ultrasound: Small, focal laceration of the splenic parenchyma with no evidence of active bleeding
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge home with symptomatic management only
Admit for observation and serial hemoglobin checks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urgent splenectomy is reserved for severe splenic injuries with hemodynamic instability or ongoing hemorrhage. This patient is stable, with a small laceration and no active bleeding, making splenectomy unnecessary and risking future immunologic compromise.

B) INCORRECT:

Discharging a patient with a splenic laceration without observation risks missing delayed hemorrhage or worsening injury. Inpatient monitoring is necessary to ensure no late decompensation, which is crucial in managing pediatric splenic trauma.

C) CORRECT:

In pediatric patients with blunt splenic injury who are hemodynamically stable, non-operative management is preferred. The ultrasound shows a small, focal laceration without active bleeding, and the patient has stable vital signs and adequate hemoglobin levels. Serial hemoglobin checks and observation are essential to detect any gradual bleeding or changes in clinical status. This approach minimizes surgical risks and preserves splenic function, which is crucial for immune competency in children.

Key learning point: In hemodynamically stable pediatric patients with minor splenic injuries, non-operative management is preferred, involving close monitoring and supportive care.

D) INCORRECT:

Immediate exploratory laparotomy is indicated in cases of hemodynamic instability or active intra-abdominal bleeding. This patient is hemodynamically stable, with normal vital signs and a small splenic laceration without active bleeding, favoring non-operative management.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of atrial fibrillation presents with a 3-day history of left upper quadrant discomfort, nausea, and intermittent fever. She denies trauma but mentions she has also experienced some left shoulder pain. Anticoagulants were recently stopped due to a gastrointestinal bleed. Physical examination shows mild splenomegaly and left upper quadrant tenderness without rebound tenderness. Vital signs are BP, 132/78; P, 95; T, 38.2°C (100.8°F). Laboratory study results show leukocytosis (WBC count 13,500/mm3) and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels (485 U/L). FAST shows no free fluid. What is the most appropriate next diagnostic step?

choices.text: MRI of the abdomen and pelvis
Contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While MRI can provide detailed soft tissue imaging, it is not the most appropriate initial diagnostic study for this patient's suspected pathology. MRI studies are time-consuming and may not be readily available in emergency settings.

B) INCORRECT:

Repeating the FAST is unnecessary as the patient is hemodynamically stable and the initial examination was negative for free fluid. This approach would delay definitive diagnosis without providing additional clinically relevant information about the suspected splenic pathology.

C) INCORRECT:

While ultrasound can detect some splenic pathology, CT is the preferred imaging study for this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic laparoscopy is invasive and inappropriate as an initial diagnostic approach, as cross-sectional imaging can determine the diagnosis noninvasively in this stable patient.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's risk factors (atrial fibrillation off anticoagulation), clinical features (left upper quadrant pain, fever, splenomegaly), and laboratory findings (leukocytosis, elevated LDH) are highly suggestive of splenic infarction. CT with contrast is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing splenic infarction, typically showing nonenhancing, subcapsular, wedge-shaped lesions that follow the spleen's segmental arterial supply. The absence of free fluid on FAST and hemodynamic stability support a nonrupture etiology.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the ED 2 hours after being knocked to the ground when he was tackled playing soccer with friends. He reports persistent left upper quadrant pain and nausea. On arrival, his vital signs are BP, 115/65; P, 95; R, 20; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F). Physical examination shows left upper quadrant tenderness and mild guarding. Initial hemoglobin is 12.5 g/dL. FAST shows free fluid in the left upper quadrant. CT abdomen with IV contrast shows a grade III splenic laceration with moderate hemoperitoneum and a small area of contrast blush. Two hours after arrival, repeat vital signs are BP, 109/60; P, 105; and repeat hemoglobin is 11.6 g/dL. The patient remains alert and oriented. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While nonoperative management is preferred for hemodynamically stable patients with splenic injuries, the presence of contrast blush indicates active bleeding. Declining hemoglobin and mild hemodynamic changes suggest ongoing hemorrhage, requiring intervention beyond observation alone.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate exploratory laparotomy is indicated for hemodynamically unstable patients or those with signs of peritonitis. This patient remains hemodynamically stable despite evidence of ongoing bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Blood transfusion addresses the consequences of hemorrhage rather than the source of bleeding. While transfusion may be needed as part of supportive care, the priority in a hemodynamically stable patient with contrast blush is to control the active bleeding before hemodynamic deterioration occurs.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Angioembolization is indicated for hemodynamically stable patients with evidence of active bleeding on imaging, such as contrast blush, pseudoaneurysms, or vascular injuries. Declining hemoglobin and contrast blush indicate ongoing hemorrhage, requiring urgent intervention to prevent further deterioration.

E) INCORRECT:

Repeat imaging inappropriately delays management when there is evidence of active bleeding on initial CT. Contrast blush and declining hemoglobin indicate ongoing hemorrhage, requiring intervention. Delaying definitive management when there are signs of clinical deterioration increases the risk of hemodynamic decompensation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with left upper quadrant pain that radiates to her left shoulder, accompanied by nausea and fever. Her past medical history is unremarkable. Vital signs are BP, 115/65; P, 95 and irregular; R, 20; T, 38.2°C (100.8°F). Physical examination shows left upper quadrant tenderness and mild splenomegaly. Laboratory study results show leukocytosis and elevated LDH. CT imaging is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Evaluate and treat the underlying atrial fibrillation
Discharge home with oral analgesics and follow-up in 48 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient’s irregular heart rate is more consistent with atrial fibrillation than thrombophilia as the cause of splenic thromboembolism.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgery is reserved for patients with complications such as postinfarction rupture, hemodynamic instability, or abscess formation. This hemodynamically stable patient with uncomplicated infarction should be managed nonoperatively.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's arrhythmia indicates that thromboembolism likely caused the splenic infarction, requiring comprehensive evaluation of the atrial fibrillation and appropriate anticoagulation management. Splenic infarctions can usually be managed conservatively with pain management and hydration.

D) INCORRECT:

Discharge is inappropriate for patients with acute splenic infarction. While many splenic infarctions are managed nonoperatively, supportive care, identification and treatment of the underlying cause, and monitoring for potential complications such as rupture or abscess are still required.

E) INCORRECT:

Angioembolization is used to treat active bleeding in traumatic splenic injuries or vascular abnormalities, not completed splenic infarction due to thromboembolism.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department after falling from a bunk bed one hour ago. He complains of left-sided abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness in the left upper quadrant without guarding or rebound. He has no other injuries (see lab result and reports).


Heart rate
90/min


Blood pressure
110/70 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
20/min


Temperature
37.2°C




Test
Result
Normal Values


Hemoglobin
120 g/L
112 - 165 g/L



FAST: Positive for a moderate fluid collection near the spleen
CT scan of abdomen: Grade II splenic laceration with no evidence of active extravasation

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Selective angiographic embolization of the spleen
Non-operative management with admission for in-hospital observation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate laparotomy and splenectomy are indicated for severe splenic injuries with hemodynamic instability or active hemorrhage. This patient has a Grade II splenic laceration without active extravasation and stable vital signs, suggesting a contained injury amenable to non-operative management. Preserving splenic function is crucial in pediatric patients to maintain immunologic competence.

B) INCORRECT:

Selective angiographic embolization is used for active arterial bleeding or high-grade splenic injuries. This patient has a Grade II splenic laceration with stable vital signs and no active extravasation on CT, favoring non-operative management. Embolization carries risks such as splenic infarction, which are significant in children where splenic preservation is important.

C) INCORRECT:

Discharging a patient with a Grade II splenic laceration and moderate fluid collection is inappropriate due to the risk of delayed hemorrhage. In-hospital observation is necessary for monitoring and prompt intervention if complications arise, even in stable patients with low-grade injuries.

D) CORRECT:

In pediatric patients with splenic injuries, non-operative management is preferred to preserve splenic function and maintain immunologic defense. This child is hemodynamically stable with a Grade II splenic laceration and no active extravasation on CT, indicating a low-grade injury suitable for non-operative management. In-hospital observation allows for monitoring of vital signs and hemoglobin levels, ensuring prompt intervention if delayed bleeding occurs. Current pediatric trauma guidelines support this approach for stable patients with low-grade splenic injuries.

Key learning point: In hemodynamically stable pediatric patients with isolated splenic injuries, non-operative management with close observation is preferred to preserve splenic function.
